channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. In addition to having a strong Perl background, must also have automated payment experience.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is on the hunt for an NLP Engineer that has strong Perl and Python and whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: Perl programmers, lean in — this is the opportunity for you if your happy place is at home in your fuzzy bunny slippers. The role is 100% remote friendly for those located in the UK, so kick back and enjoy your commute-free existence. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: As one of the most popular open-source ticketing systems on the planet, this team knows what it takes to attract organizations of all sizes. With a diverse user base that includes academic institutions, government agencies, and security teams, their software is free to download, deploy, and modify. Looking for a Perl developer with Mason, Moose, and Mojolicious.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 131
item.description: Simon used regex power to solve the task this week. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131: Splitting and Splitting More
item.description: Roger shared a Postscript solution along with Ruby. It is always the main attraction.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131
item.description: Luis shared simple and easy to follow solutions. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131: Consecutive Arrays
item.description: Just one solution this week, but very simple and easy to follow.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131: no coffee, no elegance
item.description: Luca shared a cool Raku trick as always. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #131
item.description: Beautiful solution and cool use of map. However, not easy to follow but laid out nicely.

item.title: PWC130 - Binary Search Tree
item.description: Flavio used a recursive function to solve the task. Implementation is really simple and easy to follow.

item.title: PWC130 - Odd Number
item.description: Cool use of hashes to solve the task in both Perl and Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Consecutive Limits: The Weekly Challenge
item.description: Dave made the 'Find Pairs' task look simple. Great work.

item.title: Consequential Pairings and SECRET CUTS
item.description: Colin is back with his great blog after the break. We all missed you. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #131
item.description: Cheok-Yin shared a bonus solution in Julia as well as Perl. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: Con Se Pair with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne sharing Raku hacks as always but this time we have Perl solutions too. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131: Find Pairs
item.description: Abigail once again showing Regex power, Really cool solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 131: Consecutive Arrays
item.description: Abigail is back with his one-liner in Perl. Awesome.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 129
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 131
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Consecutive Arrays" and "Find Pairs" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 132
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Mirror Dates" and "Hash Join". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Perl's File::Find on Windows: A path forward?
item.description: An interesting discussion on mixing up file-system and operating-system features and making changes to core modules.

item.description: ... and List::MoreUtils

item.title: Everyone’s a (Perl) critic, and you can be too!
item.description: The perlcritic tool is often your first defence against awkward, hard to read, error-prone, or unconventional constructs in your code.

item.title: CPAN Release of TooMuchCode 0.17
item.description: Perl::Critic::TooMuchCode is a set of policy add-ons that check for dead or redundant code.

item.title: A good old-fashioned Perl log analyzer
The ephemeral miniconf - Planning full... and frozen!
item.description: Planned to be on November 18, 2021

item.title: #531 - Legacy code
item.description:
Hi there

I like working on legacy code whether it is Perl, Python or some other language, because it is code that is already very valuable to the organization that uses it. It is great to help the maintainers understand the code better and to give them confidence in making changes to the code.

There are a number of language specific tools that can help you while dealing with legacy code. For example Perl Critic which is mentioned in at least two posts this edition. There are more generic things, like setting up a good CI system which is mentioned by Gugod.

The ideal situation is when both management and the engineers really want the change. They still probably need some external help from someone who has experience in similar situations and who has already seen systems where the engineers have no fear in making changes. It is a totally different world than what many people experience in organizations.

Enjoy your fearless week!
